title: Government of China Sends Medical Team to Morocco in 2021 (linked to projects #56311, #56319, #56331, #57182, #56341, #57440, #56345)
description: On February 2nd, 2021, a team of eleven doctors from the Jiading province in Shanghai to serve a two-year medical aid mission. As of February 2022, they have diagnosed and treated 12,600 patients and conducted 4,300 operations.  This project is part of a series of ongoing medical missions to Morocco that China has undertaken since 1975. These missions are part of the implementation of the China-Africa Public Health Cooperation Plan. As of March, 2019, a reported total of 1,784 Chinese medical personnel have been sent to aid people across Morocco.
staff_comments: 1. Other Chinese medical missions to Morocco include the following projects:Chinese Medical Mission to Morocco in 2005 (project #56311) Chinese Medical Mission to Morocco in 2010 (project #56319)Chinese Medical Mission to Morocco in 2013 (project #56331) Chinese Medical Mission to Morocco in 2015 (project #57182) Chinese Medical Mission to Morocco in 2016 (project #56341)Chinese Medical Mission to Morocco in 2017 (project #57440)Chinese Medical Mission to Morocco in 2018 (project # 56345)
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Government of China Sends Medical Team to Morocco in 2021 (linked to projects #56311, #56319, #56331, #57182, #56341, #57440, #56345)

# Description
On February 2nd, 2021, a team of eleven doctors from the Jiading province in Shanghai to serve a two-year medical aid mission. As of February 2022, they have diagnosed and treated 12,600 patients and conducted 4,300 operations.  This project is part of a series of ongoing medical missions to Morocco that China has undertaken since 1975. These missions are part of the implementation of the China-Africa Public Health Cooperation Plan. As of March, 2019, a reported total of 1,784 Chinese medical personnel have been sent to aid people across Morocco.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare services without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical team providing healthcare services, part of China-Africa Public Health Cooperation Plan

title: Chinese Government donates 200,000 Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $3.6 million in February 2021
description: On February 25, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 200,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Mozambique. A handover ceremony was held for the vaccine at Maputo International Airport, and attended by Mozambique's Prime Minister, Carlos Agostinho do Rosário, Minister of Health, Armindo Tiago, and Chinese Ambassador Wang Hejun. The vaccines were produced by the Beijing Institute of Biological Products Co. Ltd.  In 2021, the Chinese Government donated approximately 1.46 million doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Mozambique. A February donation of 200,000 doses is captured by project #95808. A People's Liberation Army donation of vaccines from June is captured in project #95811. An August donation of 200,000 doses is captured in project #95809. A final December donation of 1 million doses is captured in project #95810.
staff_comments: 1. According to the UNICEF COVID-19 Vaccine Market Dashboard, the price of a single Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine dose is $18 (https://www.oecd.org/officialdocuments/publicdisplaydocumentpdf/?cote=DCD/DAC/STAT(2022)33&docLanguage=En). As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the February 2021 donation as $3.6 million.
combined_text:

title: Chinese Government donates 1 million Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $18 million in December 2021
description: On December 13, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 1 million donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Mozambique. A handover ceremony was held in Maputo. The Chinese Ambassador to Mozambique, Wang Hejun, handed over the vaccines to Mozambican Health Minister, Armindo Tiago. At the ceremony, Ambassador Wang announced that the 1 million doses were part of the larger 1 billion pledged by Xi Jinping at the 8th Ministerial Conference of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation.   In 2021, the Chinese Government donated approximately 1.46 million doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Mozambique. A February donation of 200,000 doses is captured by project #95808. A People's Liberation Army donation of vaccines from June is captured in project #95811. As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the December 2021 donation as $18 million.

title: PLA donates 60,000 Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine doses to FADM worth $1.08 million in June 2021
description: On June 3, 2021, the People’s Liberation Army (PLA) of China delivered 60,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Mozambique Defence Armed Forces (FADM).  A handover ceremony was held at Maputo International Airport. The National Director of Military Health in the Mozambican Defence Ministry, Agueda Duarte, and the military attaché at the Chinese embassy, Zhou Zhe, jointly signed a handover certificate. Also present were Mozambique's Defense and Health Ministers, Jaime Neto and Armindo Tiago, and the Chinese ambassador, Wang Hejun. The vaccines were to be passed on to the Mozambican Health Ministry for distribution to other groups because 60,000 doses was more than FADM required.  In 2021, the Chinese Government donated approximately 1.46 million doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Mozambique. A February donation of 200,000 doses is captured by project #95808. A People's Liberation Army donation of vaccines from June is captured in project #95811. An August donation of 200,000 doses is captured in project #95809. A final December donation of 1 million doses is captured in project #95810.
staff_comments: 1. According to the UNICEF COVID-19 Vaccine Market Dashboard, the price of a single Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine dose is $18 (https://www.oecd.org/officialdocuments/publicdisplaydocumentpdf/?cote=DCD/DAC/STAT(2022)33&docLanguage=En). As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the June 2021 donation as $1.08 million.

title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Mozambique in 2021
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Mozambique signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $43,742,000 ($40,320,000 in principal payments and $3,422,000 in interest payments). However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period).   The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of Mozambique. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0. 2. The total estimated suspension amount is based on the size of the debt service deferral that the Government of Mozambique secured from the Chinese Government in 2021 (as recorded by the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System on December 6, 2022). However, another official source (https://clubofmozambique.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/05/RELATO%CC%81RIO-DA-DI%CC%81VIDA-PU%CC%81BLICA.pdf) puts the total suspension amount at $43,728,360.18. This discrepancy warrants further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Mozambique in 2021

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Mozambique signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $43,742,000 ($40,320,000 in principal payments and $3,422,000 in interest payments). However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period).   The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
justification: Debt suspension agreement with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Debt service suspension agreement, focus on financial restructuring and COVID-19 response

title: Government of China donates humanitarian aid to refugees in Mozambique following terrorist attack in October 2021
description: On October 22, 2021, the Chinese ambassador in Mozambique attended a handover ceremony of humanitarian aid to Northern Mozambique. This donation comes as a response to terrorist attacks in northern Mozambique, and is intended to help refugees affected by these attacks. The donation consisted of food (such as rice, flour, and cooking oil), medical supplies, and other goods.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Government of China donates humanitarian aid to refugees in Mozambique following terrorist attack in October 2021

# Description
On October 22, 2021, the Chinese ambassador in Mozambique attended a handover ceremony of humanitarian aid to Northern Mozambique. This donation comes as a response to terrorist attacks in northern Mozambique, and is intended to help refugees affected by these attacks. The donation consisted of food (such as rice, flour, and cooking oil), medical supplies, and other goods.
justification: Humanitarian aid project with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of food, medical supplies, and other goods to refugees

title: Government of China provides post-disaster cyclone relief supplies to Mozambique in November 2021
description: On November 1, 2021, the Chinese ambassador to Mozambique Wang Hejun attended a handover ceremony of humanitarian support in the form of food and cash assistance to Mozambique. This donation was made in cooperation with the United Nations Development Program, in order to support Mozambique after Hurricane Idai caused casualties and widespread damage in Mozambique. The goal of this assistance is to repairing 8 schools, 3 markets and 17 houses and other facilities in the disaster-stricken areas of Mozambique.  Cyclone Idai hit Mozambique in 2019, affecting hundreds of thousands of people. Directly following the cyclone, China sent aid in the form of a rescue team, as well as monetary and physical aid (see: Project ID# 87102, 97683, 97684, and 67539).
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Government of China provides post-disaster cyclone relief supplies to Mozambique in November 2021

# Description
On November 1, 2021, the Chinese ambassador to Mozambique Wang Hejun attended a handover ceremony of humanitarian support in the form of food and cash assistance to Mozambique. This donation was made in cooperation with the United Nations Development Program, in order to support Mozambique after Hurricane Idai caused casualties and widespread damage in Mozambique. The goal of this assistance is to repairing 8 schools, 3 markets and 17 houses and other facilities in the disaster-stricken areas of Mozambique.  Cyclone Idai hit Mozambique in 2019, affecting hundreds of thousands of people. Directly following the cyclone, China sent aid in the form of a rescue team, as well as monetary and physical aid (see: Project ID# 87102, 97683, 97684, and 67539).
justification: Project is focused on humanitarian aid and disaster recovery without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Post-disaster relief supplies, food and cash assistance, school and infrastructure repair

title: China donates USD $1.7 million maternity care equipment to Mozambique in March 2021
description: On March 11, 2021, the Chinese government offered a donation of medical equipment to Mozambique to help treat mothers and their newborns and will be used to help Mozambicans who were displaced by Cyclone Idai two years prior.  The equipment is worth USD $1.7 million and is able to assist around 436,000 girls and women through 32 health units. This donation will be used to assist people in the Sofala and Manica Provinces which were affected by the cyclone. This donation is under the South-South Cooperation Program, which is an agreement between China and the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA).
combined_text:

HEALTH

The equipment is worth USD $1.7 million and is able to assist around 436,000 girls and women through 32 health units. This donation will be used to assist people in the Sofala and Manica Provinces which were affected by the cyclone. justification: Project is focused on healthcare equipment donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Maternity care equipment donation, healthcare focus, no energy-related components

title: Chinese Embassy awards Chinese Ambassador Scholarship to 12 Mozambique undergraduate students in January 2021
description: On January 29, 2021, twelve undergraduate students from Mozambique's University Eduardo Mondlane received the Chinese Ambassador Scholarship. The scholarship encourages students to major in Chinese language and culture in an effort to strengthen the relationship between China and Mozambique. The monetary value of the scholarships is unknown.  An award ceremony was held for this donation at University Eduardo Mondlane in Maputo, Mozambique.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Embassy awards Chinese Ambassador Scholarship to 12 Mozambique undergraduate students in January 2021

# Description
On January 29, 2021, twelve undergraduate students from Mozambique's University Eduardo Mondlane received the Chinese Ambassador Scholarship. The scholarship encourages students to major in Chinese language and culture in an effort to strengthen the relationship between China and Mozambique. The monetary value of the scholarships is unknown.  An award ceremony was held for this donation at University Eduardo Mondlane in Maputo, Mozambique.
justification: Scholarship program focused on education and cultural exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Scholarships for undergraduate students, focus on Chinese language and culture education
